meanings.definition: Beat (someone) with a whip or stick as punishment or torture.
meanings.sent1: The cruel master would flog the poor donkey for not working hard enough.
meanings.sent2: The villain threatened to flog the captured hero if he didn't reveal the secret.
meanings.sent3: The strict teacher joked that she would flog the students with homework if they misbehaved.
meanings.sent4: The relentless storm seemed to flog the trees with its fierce winds.
meanings.sent5: The haunting memories continued to flog his conscience long after the incident.

meanings.sent1: The enthusiastic salesman would flog his products to anyone passing by.
meanings.sent2: The market trader tried to flog his old wares before the end of the day.
meanings.sent3: The persistent child would flog his toys to his friends in exchange for snacks.
meanings.sent4: The online store flogged their latest deals to attract more customers.
meanings.sent5: The auctioneer's voice echoed as he tried to flog the antique vase to the highest bidder.

meanings.definition: Promote or talk about (something) enthusiastically or excessively.
meanings.sent1: The devoted fan would flog her favorite band to everyone she met.
meanings.sent2: The company's marketing team worked hard to flog the new product to potential buyers.
meanings.sent3: The excited child would flog his upcoming birthday party to his classmates.
meanings.sent4: The politician flogged his achievements during the campaign rally.
meanings.sent5: The teacher flogged the benefits of reading to her students every day.
